RIP everything that generates with dirt on it, like mountains.

RIP Skyblock

Dirt actually is more capable of supporting itself than sand and gravel is. Obviously it isn't so much so that it could support itself horizontally like in game, but you'll notice a difference between hard dirt and sand or gravel in the real world if you try digging around in it. Having a pickaxe can actually help quite a bit when you get down two feet or so into the compressed dirt.

They would generate like sand structures, and would collapse as soon as one of them is removed.  The mountains have a layer of stone inside, so it wouldn't be a problem except in an amplified world, which would be a fun challenge anyway.
that'd just be an annoyance to be honest

A simple fix would be an attributes menu

Then we could assign gravity to block types like falls in air or rises [baloons blocks,clouds?].  and floats or sinks in water [why does chopped sand float?]. 

Also a friction ''sticky'' setting for the sides. {like sand, water and gravel } on a multiplier ......  Like:

Water=0 next to rock=50.  So friction would be 0 .but rock to dirt[5] would be 250  And dirt to dirt it would start to break off at 25 unless suported from under  .... The formula could be determined by the user 

Water should run on the ground, not disapear after a few meters or stop,   it should also pool up. So rock absorbs 0% sand 50% gravel and water 100% 

 Only absorbed by sand or gravel or lava. [it has to go somewhere ... Maybe change to steam or clouds then rain]

And rain should pool and flow becoming water source blocks .... So slimer pits become ponds ..... And while we are on the subject Mr. Mojang , ... Exploding Slimers ...... REALLY! ..... How about a ''no slime switch''... just say NO to Slime!  Some of us really hate them...

I have more but this is enough for now. ...... Just these things would radically impove the program.       last thought .... Trangles and corner slopes. Allready got it stairs ......    contact me ...I want to work at Mojang !üëçüòÉ

Hi QuantumRedston! So, I've read through your whole system, and although I do appreciate all of the time you put into it, there are many things that I don't agree with.

1) Why exactly do we need to get rid of the tipped arrows crafting recipe? It is more efficient with the potion, but costs a dragon's breath, so it seems balanced to me.

2) I don't see why the amplifications are needed, especially since "useless" is very subjective. I don't think Mojang wanted Leaping to turn you into a living trampoline. Also, Regeneration is useful because it lasts longer than golden apples and is quicker to use if in splash form.

3) Absolutely nobody will like the strategic pros and cons of potions, mainly because the cons of potions are that they are hard to get and don't stack. Add in negative effects on top of that? Forget it. Nobody would use potions anymore.

4) Dragon's milk is one of the only ideas that could make sense, but only if it were added as an alternative to milk that wouldn't clear positive effects.

5)  The bewitched milk is kind of interesting as a concept, too, but I don't think it fits with the illusioner mob.

6) I have mixed feelings about the whole Thick and Mundane potion ideas. For example, I don't think Mojang will want to add in potion versions of Mining Fatigue, Haste, or Decay, because that would make the How Did We Get Here advancement way too easy.

7) Combining potions is a definite no-no; see this reddit comment by Helen Zbihlyj to see why.

If you want to know what I think should be done to potions, you can read this post and this post. It's a much simpler, cleaner system, and I like it much better than this. Thanks for contributing your ideas, though!
Thanks for commenting! I see a lot of your points to and have already seen the other potion concepts. I've edited my concept a little (and added pictures), and have replied to most of your comments!

Gonna be honest, I'm still not a huge fan of most of your ideas, but still, immense props to you for taking criticism so well. I'll try and read everything more carefully again in the near future. The pictures are a very nice touch, too.
Thanks! I'm also redoing part 9!

• (August 2018) Mixed Potions (reference)

Ice should melt.  Please do not add any unnatural ice to Minecraft.  Just use blue stained glass or water or something.

https://feedback.minecraft.net/hc/en-us/articles/360005029872-Previously-Considered-Feedback

I had a discussion with the team yesterday (we meet regularly to talk about feedback) and we concluded things that are too similar to existing mobs or just variations on a theme probably should be avoided. You know you're veering too far into this when you're like "it's a X, but (feature) instead". Several items have fallen foul of this recently and so we want to make sure to help people create better feedback. What else could this item do? What makes it unique? Why would someone vote for this item?

This is veering pretty close to this guideline. Is there something that stained glass or water isn't doing for you? Please feel free to edit your original post and help flesh this idea out. As it is, this is also too fuzzy/vague in its current form - it doesn't even have a name.

Thanks so much. We want to help everyone have their ideas succeed and hope these ideas are useful.
'tempered ice' or something?
Compacted ice is suposed to be unmeltable

This is interesting, but I definitely don't like the idea of hay bales spontaneously combusting.  Nobody would use them anywhere if there was a chance of them catching on fire for no reason.

As to them being gravity blocks, it seems innocent enough.  But what about uses of hay bales that aren't visually storing hay?  They aren't a great thatched roof, but some people still use them as the best block available.
I agree. We should maybe add knockback Nemos instead tho
Am I the only one that thinks slimes have been forgotten.

The Protection enchantment was nerfed alongside Sharpness, and the end result is that a single attack from a Sharp V diamond sword against full Prot IV diamond armor is still greater than it was in 1.8. At least, I think the current 1.08 dmg per hit is pretty significant.

 

As for gold, I do really appreciate the idea of having all gold tools be faster variants, and I don't really see the need for them to be quite so fragile. But on the idea of attack speed for the sword, there unfortunately isn't much that can be done at the moment in that regard, because swords already swing so close to the maximum rate permitted by damage immunity. That is to say, when a player or mob is hurt, they blink red for half of a second, during which time they can't properly be hit again. The attack speed of 1.6 is already within a tenth of a second of that rate, so increasing the speed on the gold sword to 1.8, or anything else, doesn't really do much for it.

This need to be fixed. The sharpness 5 diamond sword used to have 13.5 Attack damage, but now its only 10. This thing was nerfed and I don't like it. You should still be able to have 13.5 attack damage because you have worked hard to get the enchantment. For example, a zombie is 3 hits with a sharp 5 diamond sword! It used to be 2! This is not necessary.

The Stonecutter was such a good addition, both by increasing the block efficiency when build with stone, but also for the precise control you have over the quantity of the output, minimizing excess. Having the same for wood would be a true game changer for those same reasons.
